personal: Use a professional email address. A simple format like firstname.lastname@email.com presents a professional image. Avoid informal ones like 'gamerboi123@yahoo.com'.
Always use your full legal name on your CV (first name + last name). Avoid nicknames or shortened names unless they are your official name. Example: 'Robert Mitchell'
Include a phone number you actively use and ensure your voicemail is professional.
Include a professional photo only if they have requested for it. If you add one, make sure it’s a clear, high-resolution headshot with a neutral background and professional clothing.

Write a short personal summary (2–4 sentences) to introduce yourself. Include what you’re currently doing, your strengths, and your career goals. Example: 'Recent business graduate with a strong foundation in finance and Excel. Seeking to start my career in a data-driven role within a progressive company.'
education: List your most recent education first (reverse-chronological order). Example: 'Diploma in Software Development – NZ Institute of Technology (2022–2023)'.
Include institution name, degree/diploma/certificate, location, and completion year. Example: 'Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering – KNUST, Ghana (Expected 2027)'.
If you lack work experience, add relevant coursework or academic projects. Example: 'Relevant modules: Mobile App Development, UX Design, Agile Project Management'.
If you received scholarships, awards, or honors, list them under education to highlight academic excellence.
experience: List your work experience in reverse-chronological order (most recent first). Example: 'Customer Service Assistant – The Warehouse, Auckland | May 2021 – Oct 2023'.
Include job title, company name, location, and start–end dates (month + year).
Describe your responsibilities using bullet points. (Bullet points have been inserted by default). Focus on achievements, not just tasks.
Use strong action verbs such as 'Led', 'Organised', 'Implemented', 'Improved'. Example: 'Improved order processing times by 20% by introducing a new tracking method.'
Quantify achievements when possible. Numbers make impact clear. Example: 'Handled 50+ customer inquiries daily with 95% satisfaction rate.'
If you have internships or part-time jobs, include them. Employers value transferable skills even if unrelated to the industry.
volunteer: Include volunteering roles to show community involvement and transferable skills.
Highlight leadership and teamwork roles. Example: 'Team Leader – University Food Drive: Managed 8 volunteers to distribute 500+ food parcels in 2 days.'
Show impact, not just participation. Example: 'Organised a school fundraiser that raised $2,500 for local flood relief efforts.'
If you volunteered in an area related to your career, emphasize that. Example: 'Volunteered as a coding tutor for high school students, teaching HTML and CSS.'
skills: Focus on job-relevant skills. Read the job description carefully and include matching keywords.
Separate technical and soft skills for clarity. Example: 'Technical: Microsoft Excel, Python, Tableau | Soft Skills: Teamwork, Adaptability, Critical Thinking'.
Be honest about your level of proficiency. Example: 'Python – Intermediate' or 'Excel – Advanced'.
Avoid generic skills that don’t add value, like 'Email' or 'Typing', unless specifically relevant.
projects: Include personal, academic, or freelance projects to showcase your skills, especially if you lack experience.
Give each project a title, a short description, your role, and the technologies/tools used.
Example: 'Personal Portfolio Website: Designed and built a responsive portfolio website using ReactJS and Tailwind CSS. Showcases UI/UX case studies and projects. URL: https://myname.dev'.
Example: 'Mental Health App (Team Project): Designed user flow and prototyped UI. Conducted user testing with 10 participants and iterated based on feedback.'
If available, include links to GitHub, Behance, Dribbble, or personal websites.
achievements: List achievements that demonstrate excellence, leadership, or impact.
Include academic, professional, or personal achievements relevant to the job.
Use numbers or evidence to support. Example: 'Increased Instagram followers by 150% in 6 months through content strategy and analytics.'
Example: 'Top Salesperson at Countdown (Q3 2023)' or 'Dean’s List – KNUST (2024)'.
Avoid unrelated or outdated achievements (e.g., 'Won a local chess competition in 2010') unless relevant.
languages: Only include languages you can speak.
Examples: 'French – Fluent (C1)', 'Mandarin – Intermediate (HSK Level 4)', 'Spanish – Basic Conversation'.
If bilingual or multilingual, highlight this as it’s valuable in global roles.
references: Include references only if requested. Most employers will ask at the final stages of hiring.
‘Available upon request’ is acceptable and keeps your CV clean.
If you include referees, provide their name, job title, company, phone, and email (with their permission).
Choose references who can speak about your work ethic, skills, or academic performance (e.g., former employer, manager, lecturer).
hobbies: Add hobbies that show personality or transferable skills. Choose activities that highlight qualities like leadership, creativity, or discipline. Example: 'Photography – Developed a travel blog with 10,000+ monthly views, showing creativity and consistency.'
Keep it concise and professional. Stick to 2–3 hobbies that could positively reflect on you as a candidate.
certifications: Include certifications relevant to your industry or role. Prioritize official or recognized credentials that prove upskilling, compliance, or technical expertise. Example: 'Google Data Analytics Certificate – Coursera (2024)' or 'Forklift Operator License – Worksafe NZ (valid to 2026)'.
Add the issuing organization and date of completion. This adds credibility and helps employers validate your qualifications.
checklist: Complete all required sections: Personal Info, Education, and Experience.
Double-check spelling and grammar throughout your CV.
Tailor your CV to emphasize skills and experiences relevant to the role.
Add optional sections like Skills, Languages, Projects, and References if they strengthen your profile.
Preview your CV before saving to ensure everything appears correctly.
